data.title: actors, inventors, war heroes and a King
data.meta_description: David Hemmings, Ian Fleming, William Golding, Hermione Baddeley, William Henry Fox Talbot and many more rest in Wiltshire's churchyards

Some of the most iconic characters of British history have found their final resting place in Wiltshire. Anyone from big-screen actors, to inventors, former Prime Ministers, war heroes and royalty are either buried or memorialised in one of the county's many churchyards, Cathedrals and cemeteries.

Within the bounds of our beautiful county are some gorgeous little villages with idyllic churches to visit and it might come as a surprise to some, the famous and influential people who lie resting beneath the soil.

For instance, James Bond creator, Ian Fleming famously moved to Wiltshire in the 1960s, with his second wife Ann, in a tiny village called Sevenhampton, near Swindon. This would become known as Fleming's 'final house' and remains his final resting place.

READ MORE: Hidden graveyard under the green at Salisbury Cathedral and what it means

Elsewhere, in the picturesque village of Tisbury is St John's 12 century parish church, where you can pay your respects to the parents of Rudyard Kipling, author of The Jungle Book who are buried in the cemetery. Upon a visit from WiltshireLive in 2021, an old copy of the original novel was placed at the grave's side, carefully covered by a waterproof slip - rather sweetly.

19 famous people buried in Wiltshire

WiltshireLive have compiled this list of notable people buried and memorialised in Wiltshire using the Find a Grave tool.

St. James' Churchyard in Sevenhampton

Ian Fleming (1908-1964) created the famed double agent character 007 best known as James Bond.

St Mary's Churchyard in Alvediston

Anthony Eden (1987 - 1977) was elected British Prime Minister in 1955.

St John the Baptist Churchyard in Tisbury

Dr. Martin Fleischmann (1927 - 2012) was a British chemist and physicist best known for being one of two scientists that claimed to have created the 'Cold Fusion.'

Salisbury Cathedral

William Herbert (1580 - 1630) was the Third Earl of Pembroke, matriculating from Oxford at just 13 years old and later becoming the Chancellor of the university.

Edward Heath (1916-2005) was the British Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative government from 1970 to 1974 until he was defeated as party leader by Margaret Thatcher.

Mary Sidney Herbert (1561-1621) has gone down in history as one of the most noted female authors of the Elizabethan era. She signed her published works with her own name which was thought to be very bold for an aristocratic lady.

Salisbury Crematorium

Helen Roberts (1912-2010) was a famous opera singer best known for her Gilbert and Sullivan portrayals in the 1940s.

St. Paul Churchyard in Salisbury

Jane Eyre (1626-1695) is thought to be the namesake for Charlotte Brontë's character with the same name.

St James Churchyard in Trowbridge

George Crabbe (1754 - 1832) was a famous poet in the circle of literary friends which included William Wordsworth and Sir Walker Scott. He is best known for his works The Village (1783), The Borough (1810), Tales in Verse (1812) and Tales of the Hall (1819).

St John Baptist and St Helen Churchyard in Wroughton

William Gosling (1892-1945) served as a sergeant in World War I. He was awarded a Victoria Cross for his brave actions in combat and served as a Major in the Home Guard during World War II.

Cadley Churchyard

Thomas Arthur (1835-1902) served as Gunner in the Crimean War. He was awarded a Victoria Cross for this brave actions in combat, presented by Queen Victoria.

Lacock Cemetery

William Henry Fox Talbot (1800 - 1877) was a major influence in the invention of the photograph and was one of the first photographers. Talbot holds the patent which affected the early development of photography in England.

St Mary & St Melor Churchyard in Amesbury

Hermione Baddeley (1906-1986) was a famous actress who had a 60-year-long career. She was signed by Disney to play the maid in 'Mary Poppins' (1964) and is also best known for her role as Mrs. Naugatuck in American sitcom 'Maude.' Hermione appeared on Broadway and was recognised with many accolades over her career, featuring in countless productions on and off-screen.

St Swithin Churchyard in Compton Bassett

Clement Walker Heneage (1831-1901) was a Captain in the British Army during the Indian Mutiny and received a Victoria Cross for his brave actions.

Holy Trinity Churchyard in Bowerchalke

William Golding (1911-1993) wrote the famous novel 'Lord of the Flies' - it was his very first published book and became an overnight sensation and best-seller in Britain.

St Peter Churchyard in Blackland

David Hemmings (1941-2003) was a screen actor and Motion Picture director best known for his role as the photographer in Antonio's film 'Blowup' (1966). Hemmings also appeared in 'Camelot' (1967), 'Barbarella' (1968), just to name a few and most recently, 'Gladiator' (2000) as Casius. He also directed several productions like 'Just a Gigolo' (1979).

Holy Cross Churchyard in Sherston

George Strong (1833-1888) was a Private in the Crimean War and was awarded a Victoria Cross by Queen Victoria for his brave actions.

Malmesbury Abbey

Aethelstan (c895-939) was the King of Wessex and during his reign, claimed lordship over all of Britannia, with the aim of uniting the Kingdoms under one ruler.

All Saints Churchyard in Broad Chalke

Cecil Beaton (1904-1980) was an artist, photographer and film/theatre designer who won Best Costume for blockbusters 'My Fair Lady' (1964) and 'Gigi' (1958).
